It includes the Great Pyramid of Giza, the Pyramid of Khafre, and the Pyramid of Menkaure, along with their associated pyramid complexes and the Great Sphinx of Giza. These structures were built during the Fourth Dynasty of the Old Kingdom of Ancient Egypt, around 2575–2150 BC. The Great Pyramid of Giza is the largest in Egypt and one of the largest in the world, standing at 481ft tall and covering a vast area. The pyramids were built as tombs for the pharaohs, and the Giza Plateau was once the thriving center of the ancient Egyptian capital city of Memphis. The Great Pyramid of Giza is also one of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World and is the only one to survive into modern times. The site also includes several cemeteries and the remains of a workers' village. The age of the pyramids reached its zenith at Giza, and the site is home to other Egyptian monuments such as the tomb of Pharaoh Djet of the First Dynasty and Pharaoh Ninetjer of the Second Dynasty. The Giza pyramids are among the largest structures ever built and continue to be a source of fascination and study for archaeologists, historians, and tourists.
